conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on block A in both scenarios and determine the friction force when the cylinder B is introduced.
Block A is on an inclined plane with θ = 37°.
Gravitational force on Block A is \( F_g = Mg \).
Normal force on Block A is \( N = Mg \cos(37°) \).
Friction force on Block A is \( f = \mu N \).

premise: Block A is at rest on the incline.
conclusion: The component of gravitational force along the incline is balanced by the friction force: \( Mg \sin(37°) = f \).
Block A and cylinder B are on an inclined plane with θ = 30°.
Gravitational force on Block A is \( F_g = Mg \).
Normal force on Block A is \( N = Mg \cos(30°) \).
Friction force on Block A is \( f' \).
Gravitational force on Cylinder B is \( F_g' = mg \).
Normal force on Cylinder B is \( N' = mg \cos(30°) \).
Friction force on Cylinder B is \( f'' \).

premise: Block A is at rest on the incline.
conclusion: The component of gravitational force along the incline is balanced by the friction force: \( Mg \sin(30°) = f' \).

premise: Cylinder B is at rest on the incline.
conclusion: The component of gravitational force along the incline is balanced by the friction force: \( mg \sin(30°) = f'' \).
